modulesynopsis.name: mod_proxy_hcheck
modulesynopsis.description: Dynamic health check of Balancer members (workers) for mod_proxy

summary.p: This module provides for dynamic health checking of balancer members (workers). This can be enabled on a worker-by-worker basis. The health check is done independently of the actual reverse proxy requests.
This module requires the service of mod_watchdog.

note.title: Parameters
note.p: The health check mechanism is enabled via the use of additional BalancerMember parameters, which are configured in the standard way via ProxyPass:

A new BalancerMember status state (flag) is defined via this module: "C". When the worker is taken offline due to failures as determined by the health check module, this flag is set, and can be seen (and modified) via the balancer-manager.

tr.td:

section.title: Usage examples
section.p: The following example shows how one might configured health checking for various backend servers:

In this scenario, http://www.example.com/ is health checked by sending a GET /status.php request to that server and seeing that the returned page does not include the string Under maintenance. If it does, that server is put in health-check fail mode, and disabled. This dynamic check is performed every 30 seconds, which is the default.

http://www2.example.com/ is checked by sending a simple HEAD request every 10 seconds and making sure that the response status is 2xx, 3xx or 4xx. http://www3.example.com/ is checked every 5 seconds by simply ensuring that the socket to that server is up. If the backend is marked as "down" and it passes 2 health check, it will be re-enabled and added back into the load balancer. It takes 3 back-to-back health check failures to disable the server and move it out of rotation. Finally, http://www4.example.com/ is not dynamically checked at all.

directivesynopsis.name: ProxyHCExpr
directivesynopsis.description: Creates a named condition expression to use to determine health of the backend based on its response.

usage.p: The ProxyHCExpr directive allows for creating a named condition expression that checks the response headers of the backend server to determine its health. This named condition can then be assigned to balancer members via the hcexpr parameter
usage.note: The expression can use curly-parens ("{}") as quoting deliminators in addition to normal quotes.
usage.p: If using a health check method (eg: GET) which results in a response body, that body itself can be checked via ap_expr using the hc() expression function, which is unique to this module.
In the following example, we send the backend a GET request and if the response body contains the phrase Under maintenance, we want to disable the backend.

example.title: ProxyHCExpr: Checking response body
example.highlight: ProxyHCExpr in_maint {hc('body') !~ /Under maintenance/} ProxyPass "/apps" "http://backend.example.com/" hcexpr=in_maint hcmethod=get hcuri=/status.php

usage.p: NOTE: Since response body can quite large, it is best if used against specific status pages.

directivesynopsis.name: ProxyHCTemplate
directivesynopsis.description: Creates a named template for setting various health check parameters

usage.p: The ProxyHCTemplate directive allows for creating a named set (template) of health check parameters that can then be assigned to balancer members via the hctemplate parameter

example.title: ProxyHCTemplate
example.highlight: ProxyHCTemplate tcp5 hcmethod=tcp hcinterval=5 ProxyPass "/apps" "http://backend.example.com/" hctemplate=tcp5

directivesynopsis.name: ProxyHCTPsize
directivesynopsis.description: Sets the size of the threadpool used for the health check workers.

usage.p: If Apache httpd and APR are built with thread support, the health check module will offload the work of the actual checking to a threadpool associated with the Watchdog process, allowing for parallel checks. The ProxyHCTPsize directive determines the size of this threadpool. If set to 0, no threadpool is used at all, resulting in serialized health checks. The default size is 16.
